awd_titl_txt: A Bioarchaeological And Isotopic Study Of Social Organization, Violence, Health And Diet
awd_abstract_narration:
This research examines what happens to people when social institutions fail. It builds on theories of state collapse, which posit that the power void left by a collapsed state leads to social unrest, the demise of social institutions, poor health, and warfare. Recent theoretical frameworks, however, challenge the notion of unmitigated collapse and argue for a more nuanced examination of the afterlife of states and empires. That is, because illness, malnutrition, and trauma are often seen as inevitable in a poor natural environment, other factors are often overlooked. For example, health outcomes are also affected by social relations, trade networks, and human decisions about how to manage the natural environment and equitably (or inequitably) distribute resources. While climate stress can contribute to serious deleterious effects on human health and livelihood, these effects are mediated through historical precedence, political decision-making, social networks, and social norms that may dictate or encourage certain behaviors, all of which can impact community and individual health.

Dr. Tiffiny A. Tung and her international research team of students and professionals will investigate how the prehistoric PeruvianWari state decline and a subsequent period of climate stress affected the health, diet, violence, and migration patterns of populations from the ancient Peruvian Andes. Over 400 human skeletons from three sequential time periods are examined: Terminal Wari (AD 1000-1100); 2) Late Intermediate Period I (LIP, AD 1100-1275); and 3) LIP II (AD 1275-1400). The skeletal remains from each era are examined for trauma and pathological lesions, excellent proxies for documenting levels of violence and community health; changes in social identity are examined through cranial modification; dietary practices are reconstructed through a study of carbon and nitrogen isotope ratios and dental disease; migration patterns are documented through strontium and lead isotope ratios; and estimates of precipitation and climate are reconstructed with oxygen isotope ratios from human and animal dental apatite. The data from each time period are compared to evaluate the distinct effects of state decline and the subsequent period of incipient drought and later severe, persistent drought. 

This project gives students from the US and Peru hands-on experience in osteological analysis and archaeological studies, while also fomenting international collaborations and mutual respect. Unidentified human bodies from the Peruvian conflict of the 1980s also means that the PI's bioarchaeological team can coordinate with the local forensic teams in certain human rights/forensic cases, especially as it relates to documenting and interpreting skeletal trauma.

por.por_cntn:
This research examines how the decline of the Wari Empire and a concurrent and subsequent drought structured violence, health, diet, patterns of infectious disease, migration, and corporal expressions of identity among those who lived in the former Wari imperial heartland. The skeletons are from sites in Ayacucho, Peru. Fifty AMS dates show that they span the Terminal Wari to Late Intermediate period (LIP). A previous NSF-DDIG-funded project by this PI examined Wari-era skeletons, thus allowing for comparisons of morbidity, diet, and migration from the time of Wari imperial emergence, through its decline, and into the 300 years after imperial collapse.

Archaeological human skeletons from the sites of Huari, Qasa Pampa, and Aya Machay were analyzed for this study. The bioarchaeological and stable isotope analyses demonstrate that the post-imperial era and centuries of drought were characterized by violence, the unequal distribution of dietary resources, limited migration to the imperial core, distinct experiences with violence based on social identity (as gleaned from cranial modification styles), the emergence of tuberculosis, and desecration of corpses.

Skeletal trauma analysis shows that slightly more than half of the population suffered sublethal violence and a third died from physically violent attacks; those frequencies represent a significant increase relative to the preceding Wari era. Both sexes and all age groups (excluding infants) were victims of deadly violence. The patterning of lethal cranial fractures suggests that many adult males and children were systematically killed with blows to the posterior of the head. Individuals with cranial modification experienced significantly more sublethal head trauma than those without cranial modification, suggesting that one social group may have been targeted for more mundane forms of violence than the other. However, both groups similarly experienced deadly violence (similar frequencies of perimortem cranial fractures).

Stable carbon isotope analysis reveals significant gender differences in particular aspects of diet. For example, the consumption of maize—a culturally and politically valued food in the Andes—significantly declined from Wari to post-Wari times, but only for adult women. Further, among 161 post-Wari adults for whom skeletal sex could be estimated, men consumed significantly more maize than women. This sex-based difference in diet did not emerge until after puberty; isotope data from dental enamel (forms during childhood years) shows that boys and girls had identical access to maize. Those data suggest that dietary differences did not emerge until after gender norms and gender roles were more fully constituted. In short, maize was produced, but social and political decision-making led to the unequal distribution of this resource.

Stable nitrogen isotope ratios (δ15N) significantly increase from Wari to post-Wari times for men, women, and children, but this did not result from more marine food consumption. Sulfur isotope analysis demonstrates the absence of marine foods in the diet. Instead, the higher δ15N could have resulted from the combination of a more arid environment, which likely led to the manuring of crops as they attempted to maintain agricultural production levels during a severe drought, and episodes of starvation.

Stable oxygen isotope analysis and preliminary strontium isotope analysis show that there were few first-generation migrants to Huari in post-Wari times. However, collaborative, preliminary ancient DNA data from post-Wari individuals at Huari hints at the possibility that there was population replacement in the second half of the LIP, some 200 years after Wari imperial decline. Future studies will explore this in greater detail to understand the population dynamics and generational migration patterns during and after periods of social upheaval and climate stress.

Amid this context of violence, unequal distribution of food, and possible bouts of starvation, a new infectious disease emerged: tuberculosis (TB). Paleopathological analysis documented lesions on the vertebrae indicative of TB, and collaborative, preliminary studies have documented ancient DNA from Mycobacterium tuberculosis, undergirding the interpretation that TB spread throughout this post-Wari community. This infectious disease has not been observed in the preceding Wari era, but emerged as the Wari empire was declining, and also appears 200 years after imperial decline during a severe and extended drought. Ongoing and future studies aim to examine the origin and spread of TB in this region.

These analyses show extreme hardship for people who lived in the Wari imperial heartland after its political decline, and taphonomic studies of the skeletal elements reveal that corporal treatment after death was similarly harsh. More than 80% of the several thousand skeletal elements exhibit cut marks, indicating that the corpses were defleshed and demuscled. The evidence for this particular post-mortem treatment, combined with the data on violence-related trauma, suggest that the bodies were mutilated and desecrated. In all, the bioarchaeological, isotopic, and preliminary DNA data reveal that the communities living in this post-imperial drought era experienced extreme levels of violence and other hardships, but that certain experiences, such as food access or exposure to violence, were structured by social identity, age, and gender.
